prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Observe the SPIRITS 14ajc field in the galaxy M83
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We seek to observe the location of SPIRITS 14ajc, a luminous IR_only transient detected by the Spitzer Space Telescope to determine if it is a luminous flare form a forming groups of massive protostars, a merger of a compact main-sequence, binary, or a buried or extincted supernova. We will measure the dust continuum and CO 4-3, and the HCN, CS, and HCO+ transitions that fall into Band 7 with 1" angular resolution.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: For typical GMC lines, we get roughtly 5 resolution elements accross the profile. The large bandwidth is needed to maximize contiumm sensitivity.

At the typical distance to the SPIRITS sources, (5 Mpc for M83). 0.5" second resolution is chosen because that is the error in the position of the Spitzer SPIRITS transients. At 5 Mpc, 0.5" corresponds to about 12 pc, about half the typical size scale of giant molecular clouds in galactic spiral arms. All selected transients are located in major spiral arms which are extended and stretch across the beam. Their widths are of order 100 hundred pc (2 to 5).

Typical giant molecular cloud linewidths are 5 km/s. Thus 1 km/s resolution is sufficient to measure the linewidths in CO, HCN, HCO+, and CS. In massive star forming complexes, the lines can be broadened considerably by velocity gradients and forcing by various feedback effects to 10s of km/s. We also need to maximize our continuum sensitivity. Thus, we use the full available bandwidth in each baseband. Typical cluster and massive-star forming clumps have sizes of order 1 pc. Thus, they will be beam diluted in our observations. Hot core CO line temperatures of 100 K, similar to Orion will be diluted from in our 0.5" beam by a factor of ~100, making the clumps have a CO temperature of 1 K in our beam. HCN, CS, and HCO+ lines will be a factor of 2 to 5 dimmer. Thus, we need 0.1 K sensitivity per beam. ,An Orion line explosion or an SN in a GMC can heat CO to several hundred to even thousands of K, but only reach dimensions of order 0.1 pc. However, the radiative flash can illuminate a parsec scale region in a few years. The heating effects of a buried SN flash can be detected of a few hundred mK.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The Spitzer SPIRITS program has identified dozens of infrared-only transients with luminosities between novae and supernovae but no visual-wavelength counterparts. Most are located in star-forming galaxies along dust lanes and spiral arms. Some may be obscured supernovae or Type II SNe deeply embedded inside molecular clouds. Others may be the mergers of main-sequence stars in compact binaries. Some may be massive protostars in non-hierarchical multiple star systems that re-arrange to form massive, compact binaries. The release of gravitational potential energy during the dynamical formation of such doubles in 3- and 4-body AU-scale encounters can eject the stars, circumstellar gas, and produce long-lasting, luminous IR flares. A similar 10^48 erg event occurred in Orion 500 years ago. We propose to observe the fields around 7 SPIRITS IR transients to determine if they are in a star-forming environment, embedded in or behind a cloud.
